title: J&J says Covid booster shot produced strong antibody response
text:
A booster shot of Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 vaccine produced a strong and rapid antibody response against the virus, the pharmaceutical company said on Wednesday.

The preliminary data from the world's largest healthcare company came as top US public health officials and rival vaccine makers said a booster shot programme was needed to protect against waning immunity.

J&J said a second shot elicited a nine-fold increase in antibodies against Covid compared with levels seen 28 days after a single dose of the jab.

“Significant increases” in antibody responses were seen in people aged 18 to 55, as well as those older than 65, who were given a lower dose.

Unlike the BioNTech/Pfizer and Moderna two-dose mRNA shots, J&J's primary vaccine requires only one jab. J&J previously said its single shot provided broad immunity against Covid for eight months.

Mathai Mammen, global head of Janssen Research & Development at Johnson & Johnson, said the company looked forward to “discussing with public health officials a potential strategy for our Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine, boosting eight months or longer after the primary single-dose vaccination”.

The rollout of booster shots has been hotly debated, with the World Health Organization urging rich countries to pause programmes until at least 10 per cent of the global population has been vaccinated.

The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has recommended people with weakened immune systems receive a booster dose of an mRNA jab, but has held back from recommending anything for those who have received the J&J vaccine.

The agency announced a plan last week to begin offering booster shots from September 20 to all Americans who were vaccinated with the Moderna or BioNTech/Pfizer jabs, starting with those who were inoculated eight months ago. It said that a plan for J&J vaccine recipients would be made when more data was available.

Pfizer and BioNTech on Wednesday became the first companies to apply for full US regulatory approval for their booster shot.

Studies showing that vaccine efficacy waned over time have fuelled the debate around additional doses, especially as cases begin rising again in some countries.

A CDC study on Tuesday showed that mRNA vaccine efficacy against infection from the highly transmissible Delta variant decreased from 91 per cent to 66 per cent.

An Oxford university study published last week showed that efficacy of the Pfizer vaccine against symptomatic infection almost halved after four months.

Source: Nikou Asgari in New York 2021 'J&J says Covid booster shot produced strong antibody response' FT.com 25 August. Used under licence from the Financial Times. © The Financial Times Limited 2021. All Rights Reserved.
